text.p: These are the leading stories in the Egyptian press on Saturday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- President Hosni Mubarak, at a meeting today with the political group of ministers, will discuss Egypt's pivotal role in the peace process and the contacts under way to break the deadlock in negotiations between the Israeli government and the Palestinian Authority. At the same time Mubarak will receive Palestinian President Yasser Arafat.

They will discuss a five-point plan for reviving the negotiations. The five points are: 1. Refraining from making any changes in the status of Jerusalem from now on. 2. Stopping settlement projects in the West Bank "for a sufficient period" 3. The Palestinians would give a firm commitment to take all measures to ensure Israel's security 4. Israel would give a firm commitment to implement all the articles agreed in the Hebron agreement, including allowing Gaza airport to open, work to start on Gaza port and a corridor linking the West Bank and Gaza Strip to open 5. an immediate start to final status negotiations to run in parallel with implementation of the Hebron agreement. The next withdrawals of Israeli forces from the West Bank would also take place by consensus between the Palestinian and Israeli sides, not according to Israel's wishes alone.

- The Ministry of the Interior has taken rapid steps to deal with violence and thuggery. Interior Minister Hassan el-Alfi said a draft amendment was being prepared to the law on the possession of firearms and other weapons. The amendment will introduce stiffer penalties.
- Foreign Minister Amr Moussa received a letter from Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov on the Middle East.
- Prime Minister Kamal Ganzouri will head a high-level delegation to the Crans-Montana economic conference which begins on June 26.

- A mission from the largest rating agency in Europe (IBCA) will arrive in Cairo this week to do a complete assessment of the Egyptian economy at the request of big investors and international companies and banks.

- The Arab Fund for Development has agreed to lend Egypt $300 million -- $100 million to build pumping stations for the Toshka project, $100 million for the Shorouq housing project, $50 million for Social Fund for Development and $50 million for new projects to be identified by Egypt.
- Syrian ambassador Issa Darwich said any Arab country was free to sign up to the Egyptian-Syrian document on an Arab common market, if they wanted to and were ready.
- An official of the International Finance Corporation told Le Figaro that the corporation was thinking of investing $200 million in Egypt in the next few years.
